funder.name: Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada

abstract: <jats:p>The North American fauna of <jats:italic>Drymeia</jats:italic> Meigen was studied. Four new species are described (<jats:italic>Drymeia hucketti</jats:italic><jats:bold>sp. nov.</jats:bold>, <jats:italic>Drymeia ponti</jats:italic><jats:bold>sp. nov.</jats:bold>, <jats:italic>Drymeia vockerothi</jats:italic><jats:bold>sp. nov.</jats:bold>, <jats:italic>Drymeia woodorum</jats:italic><jats:bold>sp. nov.</jats:bold>), and three new synonymies are proposed: <jats:italic>Drymeia amnicola</jats:italic> (Huckett, 1966) (= <jats:italic>Drymeia rivalis</jats:italic> (Huckett, 1966), <jats:bold>syn. nov.</jats:bold>); <jats:italic>Drymeia glacialis</jats:italic> (Rondani, 1866) (= <jats:italic>Drymeia alpicola</jats:italic> (Rondani, 1871), <jats:bold>syn. nov.</jats:bold>); and <jats:italic>Drymeia spinitarsis</jats:italic> (Aldrich, 1918) (= <jats:italic>Drymeia longiseta</jats:italic> Sorokina &amp; Pont, 2015, <jats:bold>syn. nov.</jats:bold>). An annotated checklist, DNA barcodes (when available), and keys for each sex of the 24 named species of North American <jats:italic>Drymeia</jats:italic> are provided. The utility of DNA barcodes for the identification of <jats:italic>Drymeia</jats:italic> species across a wide geographical range was explored using sequences from five countries. A match between morphology and DNA barcodes was found for 71% (22/31) of species studied (including three unnamed taxa). The remaining nine species clustered into two groups of taxa with very little interspecific variation within clusters (groups of two and seven species). Caution is advised against using DNA barcoding as the only determination tool for <jats:italic>Drymeia</jats:italic> material without prior knowledge of its limitations for certain species groups.</jats:p>
title: Review of the North American fauna of Drymeia Meigen (Diptera, Muscidae) and evaluation of DNA barcodes for species-level identification in the genus
